Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 06 August 2025

Distinguishing the flow of airborne microorganisms along with environmental conditions and their influence on historic heritage buildings
                    L. de-Lemos-Medina 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3795-73541,2, A. Bermúdez-Marín3, D. Jaikel-Víquez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3553-53934,5,6, N. Camacho-Cambronero4, A. Segura-Vargas4, A. Gómez-Arrieta4, Y. Mora-Quirós5, K. Ureña-Alvarado7, L. Rautenberg8, I. Fonseca-Alfaro9,10, P. Calderón-Mesén5,11, M. Sandoval-Gutiérrez12, M. Redondo-Solano4,6,13 & …O. A. Herrera-Sancho 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8871-171X5,9,10,14 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 28750 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Air microbiologyCharacterization and analytical techniquesEnvironmental healthEnvironmental impactEnvironmental monitoring

AbstractThe National Theater of Costa Rica is a national symbol of our country and an important architectural landmark. It was built in 1897 and is decorated with large-format paintings made by Italian artists. One of these painters was Paolo Serra, who was in charge of decorating three chambers, including the Management’s Office (MO). A yearly volumetric air sampling was conducted in seven rooms of the theater, showing high levels of circulating fungal spores in the MO. Thus, further analysis was carried out in this venue. First, the environmental conditions (wind velocity, temperature, relative humidity, and particles) were monitored. Then, the air and particles’ flow and the probability of particles concentration were simulated for different scenarios of natural ventilation using a Discrete Phase Model. This allowed us to identify areas where damage and microorganisms were probably more prevalent. The artworks in this chamber were analyzed to determine the types of damages identified: buckling, cracks, cuts, craquelure, holes, scratches, color gaps with exposed fabric or wall, insect debris, flaking, humidity stains, interventions of old restorations, opaque stains, whitish stains and total loss of the original image. As a complement, a microbiological sample was held in 34 sites of interest, resulting in the isolation and identification of five bacterial isolates and thirteen fungi. We identified the artist’s main colour palette: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine and natural barite. We can conclude that artworks under non-controlled environmental conditions may present a significant degree of deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration.

IntroductionCultural historical buildings represent a form of expression which frames certain feelings and describes the social and economical state of societies within a given moment. It is necessary to preserve these constructions for the next generation because of their great historical value, which allows us to understand various aspects of societies, such as their history and development. These cultural heritage conservation processes are supported by a series of problem-solving perspectives and tools that allow the identification of materials and considerations from the point of view of technique and technology used by artists for their intentions and creative process1,2,3,4,5. Little is known about the environmental impact of geographical location on heritage buildings, especially of those located in tropical countries, along with the intention of its construction and it is not clear what factors represent a key challenge to ensure the conservation of the artworks in these atmospheres.Therefore, this pilot study seeks to remedy these challenges by analyzing the environmental conditions of the Management’s Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR [built in 1891-1897]) and to determine their impact on the large-format paintings located within this chamber (see Fig. 1 for our artistic visualization). The NTCR is a historical building that represents society’s desire to experience various expressions of art locally, like other theaters’ intent throughout Europe and Latin America6. In this building, the south and east sides are lined with typically busy streets (pedestrians and vehicles), while the north and west sides have a plaza where many pigeons live and where people pass through all day long. The MO is located in the southwest corner of the building (Fig. 2) and is decorated with wall-to-wall murals and a large-format oil painting on the ceiling, all painted by Italian artist Paolo Serra. Environmental conditions play an important role in the maintenance of these historic buildings, especially those that shelter important artworks that are exposed to climate changes and different conditions since the time of its construction7,8. Therefore, environmental conditions could be a major factor, causing degradation damage to historic heritage if there are no climatized systems that keep the temperature and relative humidity under control, independently of the external conditions. Another important practical implication is that when the historic buildings are open to the public, there are greater probabilities that the temperature, humidity, airborne microorganisms, internal microclimate, and the energy performance of the entire system will vary8.To a limited extent, three methods have been identified as being potentially important for keeping the internal environmental conditions of historic buildings under control: (1) natural ventilation, (2) forced ventilation and (3) air conditioning. Most historic buildings were designed and built using natural ventilation (1), accordingly, it is an additional challenge to make modifications that allow the inclusion of any of the other types of techniques, namely (2) and (3), especially in those that contain cultural heritage without causing structural harm or several major drawbacks to the artworks9. It has been shown that there is an unambiguous relationship between temperature variations and paintings, specifically thermal fatigue could be generated, which has possible connections to the artworks’ damages10. It is worth mentioning that the NTCR only has an air conditioning system in the main chamber, yet the rest of the rooms do not have controlled environmental conditions. The MO chamber has three large windows that are periodically opened. The artworks are not exposed to the public, except for special visitors with controlled access, including diplomats, researchers, conservators, restorers, and visitors by appointment or formal invitation. The access door to this room is located on the north side, next to the main entrance of the building. Once inside, one can appreciate the large format paintings that delicately decorate all the walls and ceiling of the chamber. The study’s objective was to examine these large-format paintings exhibited under non-controlled environmental conditions from an interdisciplinary viewpoint for evidence findings that methodically assess the conservation state, i.e. the deterioration and biodeterioration, chromatic alteration, and the artist’s color palette (Fig. 1). Finally, our aim is therefore to provide a systematic correlation between these parameters and deterioration that can be identified in the artworks. It is worth mentioning that in previous works at the NTCR, we observed a new fungal species associated with damaging cultural heritage11: we distinguished particular fluorescent areas which were recognized through its red-coral fluorescence as Madder Lake12, we identified Carlo Ferrario’s main colour palette, along with we successfully achieved the characterization of eight genera of calcareous nannofossils found in the ground layers of his artwork13. Carlo Ferrario was an Italian artist, who was commissioned to paint Musas I and Musas II, two of the most important and representative paintings of the NTCR. However, our goal of having a deeper understanding of the inexorable complexity which surrounds the artwork’s habitat, colour modification suitable to environmental adaptation, and the pictorial materials used by artists from respective epochs to devise a historic building that has remained elusive.Fig. 1Multidisciplinary approach to the study of the effect of environmental conditions on the artworks found in the Management’s Office of the National Theater of Costa Rica. This study aims to describe how temperature, relative humidity, air flow and microbial colonization have deteriorated the murals, and the ceiling painted by the Italian artist Paolo Serra. The room is decorated with Pompeian inspired art and is located at the entrance of the theater, in the southwest corner. As shown in the illustration, it has three windows facing the outside environment where air, light and diverse microorganisms can enter the venue. Evelyn María Zamora Conejo partially created the figure. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageFig. 2Location of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR). (A) The MO is located in the southwest corner of the NTCR, bordered to the south by one of the Capitals’ main streets, and a plaza, filled with pigeons and pedestrians, to the west. (B) The room has three windows that are usually open throughout the week and a door that leads to the theater’s entrance hallway. As shown in the panel (C), the room is completely decorated with paintings by Italian artist Paolo Serra, in a clear Pompeian style. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imagePaolo SerraPaolo Serra was an Italian painter trained at the academies of Naples and Florence. Later, he worked as a teacher at the Academy of Rome. After that, he traveled to Costa Rica to fulfill a contract that entrusted him with painting part of the decorative artworks of the NTCR. Upon completing these paintings, he settled permanently in the country where he carried out other commissions, such as the paintings for the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Heredia, the old Casa Cural of the Villa de Barva in Heredia, and the Chapel of the Hospicio Carlos María Ulloa. Unfortunately, out of these three places, only the painting of Hospicio has survived14,15.Serra’s style was distinguished by its dynamism, intense chromaticism, and a clear influence by Pompeian murals. He used to decorate his paintings with decorative borders, frequently using repeated motifs that he may have executed using molds. There are variations in the painter’s signatures: in some of the works at the NTCR, he signed as Paolo, while in others he used the name Pablo. This could be due to an adaptation to the Latin American context of the time or, perhaps, to the fact that one of his assistants signed on his behalf, a common practice at that time. For this research, two types of artworks were analyzed: oil on canvas attached to the ceiling and a mural on the west elevation composed of four paintings to complete the chamber known as MO. Both artworks were produced in 1897 by Paolo Serra (1860-1900), as part of the construction of the NTCR. In addition to the mural paintings at the NTCR, a few easel works are known, such as landscapes, still life, and portraits, which are currently part of private collections. Paolo Serra died on December 9, 1900, in the city of Heredia at the age of 40.Results and discussionIdentification of deteriorations in the artworks under studyPhotographs in the visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) spectrum were generated for each of the paintings studied. Examples of these pictures are presented in Figs. 2B, 5, and 6. Based on the analysis of the photographs and ocular inspection carried out in situ at the NTCR, several damages and significant deterioration were identified. As a guide to determine the type of damage the following bibliography was consulted: Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Material Inc (AICCM)16, Mayorga17 and Calvo18. Supplementary Table 2 shows the definition and general characterization of these deteriorations found and Table 1 presents the identification number, name and percentage of damage, and the quadrants in which each is presented in the painting of the MO ceiling. For example, cracks were identified in all the quadrants. The damages are also illustrated with an image of the actual damage found in each of the artworks in question and their location according to the previously established grid. Fig. 5B illustrates the damages found in the painting of the ceiling. It is worth mentioning that, as an example of the identification of the damages, a zoom of the grid number 28 is presented, which has many damages identified by different colors: cracking, cracks, excrement of insects, opaque spots, exposed support, holes, and scratches.Table 1 Table of damages by quadrant on Management Office ceiling (Danthe y Rafael).Full size tableAerial microorganisms contamination of the NTCRThe fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the NTCR (i.e. Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men’s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, MO, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Theater Box, see Supplementary Figure S1) was determined throughout the year 2022. As described in the Methods section, one monthly sampling was carried out, except for June and December for reasons beyond the control of the study. In June, Hurricane Bonnie prevented visitors from entering the facility, and in December the NTCR was closed for the holiday season. Therefore, the results reflect data collected during the ten months of the year under study.Table 2 shows the fungal aerial concentration by cubic meter of the seven rooms sampled. The highest mean concentration was found in the Hall attached to the Ladies’ Cafeteria (1355 ± 459 spores/m³) and the lowest in the Smoking Lounge for Ladies (701 ± 275 spores/m³). However, the NTCR MO presented the highest concentration of all the samplings during April (4408 spores/m³). This was the month that presented the highest mean fungal concentration (1610 ± 1368 spores/m³), while July was the lowest (548 ± 174 spores/m³). Significant statistical differences were found between the fungal aerial concentration of each month (F = 2.264; df = 9; p = 0.03). The data was divided into three groups: the first group included the months of March and July, the second group January, February, May, August, September, October, and November; and only April in the third group. This indicates that the months with lower concentrations (March and July) presented significant differences respect to the other months of the year, which in turn, showed significant differences compared to April, the month with the highest concentration. It is worth noting that the high fungal concentrations found in April are due to the levels found in the NTCR’s MO. In Fig. 3A, the boxplot graphic of the monthly measurements of the fungal aerial concentration of all the rooms sampled is presented and includes specifically the value of Cladosporium spp. fungal spore concentration since this is presented in the biggest amount, so that is the most representative. It is worth mentioning that similar results have been documented for other indoor environments in Costa Rica. In a study conducted inside three schools located in the Province of Heredia, high fungal aerial concentrations were reported during the months of May and October (rainy season, ranging from 3194 to 3747 spores/m³) and the lowest on March (1392 ± 120 spores/m³). Once again, the main fungal spore identified belonged to the genus Cladosporium19. On the other hand, a study analyzing the fungal aerial concentration of the outside environment of an academic institution found much lower concentrations with a yearly mean of 444 ± 202 spores/m³. Eighteen types of spores were identified, the majority of which were sexual spores20. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. The second set of nine measurements were taken once in the center of the room, by the south window, and by the east window closest to the door (see Fig. 4A and Supplementary Figure S3) with three scenarios of one window open, both windows open and closed windows. Outside each window, measurements were also taken.Because the atmospheric station had three wind speed sensors arranged in a triangular configuration, the x-axis and y-axis wind speed measurements were calculated using the following equations:$$\begin{aligned} & V_{x} = V_{1}-\frac{(V_{2}+V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V_{y} = \frac{\sqrt{3}(V_{2}-V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V = \sqrt{V_{x}^{2}+V_{y}^{2}}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                where \(V_{1}\), \(V_{2}\), and \(V_{3}\) indicate the speed measured by the sensors [m/s]; \(V_{x}\), \(V_{y}\), V correspond to the wind speed in the x, y axis [m/s], and its magnitude, respectively.The analysis for the mass flow of the particles was made with a fixed box model, which is used for air pollution analysis in cities described by De Nevers41. These models establish a mass balance in the control volume of the air in the city to be zero (i.e. \(m_{entrance}-m_{exit}=0\)). In accordance, in this model, the entrance flow is the particle flow entering through the south (or west) windows and the particles created in the room, which are assumed to be zero. The exit flow consists of particles exiting through the opposite west (or south) windows and the particles accumulated on the paintings and the mural of the east wall.The mass flow, \(\dot{m}\), is therefore calculated using the wind speed magnitude (see Equation 3), concentration of particles in the air and the cross-sectional area of the window when they enter the room, following this relationship:$$\begin{aligned} \dot{m} = c\cdot V\cdot A_{t}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                here c denotes the air pollution concentration [\(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\)] and \(A_{t}\) is related to the cross-sectional area of the entrance [\(\hbox {m}^{2}\)]. As a consequence, the entering particles can be considered suspended particles as the terminal sedimentation velocity is several orders of magnitude less than the local wind speed. The sedimentation terminal speed, \(V_{s}\), can be calculated with the Stokes law, as the particle’s size D are between 1 \({\upmu }\)m to 10 \({\upmu }\)m, given by:$$\begin{aligned} V_{s} = gD^{2}(\frac{\rho _{p}-\rho _{air}}{18\mu }), \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                where g corresponds to the gravity (9.81 \(\hbox {m/s}^{2}\)), \(\rho _{p}\) indicates the particle’s density = 2000 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), assuming that the air particles are similar in size to carbon, \(\rho _{air}\) is the air’s density = 1.2 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), and \(\mu\) correspond to the air’s dynamic viscosity = \(1.8x10^{-5}\) Pa\(\cdot\)s.Simulation of flow and accumulation’s probability of particlesUsing the measurements of the chamber, a 3D model was made in the platform for modelling Fusion \(360^{\circledR }\) for the control volume. This was imported to the software ANSYS 2023 R2 where an air flow simulation of the room was done. For the model, we considered a scenario where the south and west windows are open. According to the cleaning personnel, this is the most frequently used scenario. The mesh size is 0.1 m, using over 900 thousand elements, while there is a maximum of 1 million elements in this case. The east wall and the ceiling were considered as a particle trap to determine the number of particles trapped from the surrounding pollution.The model used for the analysis is a dense discrete particle model (DDPM) to incorporate the wind flow and the particle flow entering the room. The particles flow and the wind flow are inserted in the normal direction to the entrance of the windows at an average temperature of \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, a dispersion parameter of 4, a rosin-rammler distribution for the minimum diameter of 1 \(\mu\)m, an average diameter of 4.8 \(\mu\)m obtained from the room measurements and a maximum diameter of 10 \(\mu\)m. The mass flow is dependent on the velocity so for each case the mass flow is calculated keeping the cross-sectional area and the particle concentration constant. The simulation configuration will be with a stationary phase model, the standard K-\(\epsilon\) viscosity model, gravity, and the energy equation are included. In this measuring instrument, colors are represented using coordinates in a uniform color space consisting of variable luminosity \(L^{*}\) and chromaticity indices \(a^{*}\) and \(b^{*}\). For this case, \(L^{*}\) indicates the scale from black to white, a negative value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color green, a positive value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color red, a negative value of the parameter \(b^{*}\) corresponds to blue and a positive value of \(b^{*}\) indicates closer to color yellow. The measurement of \(L^{*}\) (around 4-6 experimental points per zone) was carried out in all the regions previously established as areas of interest due to the high probability that particles would settle there, based on the simulation carried out with the ANSYS computer tool. As a consequence, it would be expected that, in the northern region of this painting, the variation of the \(L^{*}\) parameter would decrease since a lower value of \(L^{*}\) means a darker luminosity. Thus, \(L^{*}\) has been plotted as a function of the position on the grid of the painting (regions close to the frame), where the number 1 corresponds to the region closest to the windows, i.e. the western region of the NTCR, and 6 corresponds to the region closest to the west wall.                     (6)

Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape. Subsequently, the fragments were analyzed in a JEOL JSM-IT 500 scanning electron microscope under variable pressure, utilizing backscattered electron imaging to assess their structural characteristics.
